ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: While AFAM 480 was, of course, a place for me to work on and think about my own thesis, it was also a place for convening, not merely by learning about my peers projects but also by engaging with texts and media that, even if apparently unrelated to all our projects, were nevertheless relevant to the field of African American Studies as a whole. There was something incredibly refreshing about a space of learning that acknowledged the merit and importance of black studies both when in service to a particular project and when not.

During my time in this class, I learned different ways to synthesize and organize information I've collected through research. Furthermore, working with classmates who had related interests, I was able to collaborate with them to use strategies that they employed, and build my work from their critiques. Lastly, though being encouraged to present my work, I was able to gain a greater understanding of my own topic through having to articulate it to others.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I felt, by the end of the semester, that our AFAM 480 class had developed into a genuinely communal space, and the feedback and suggestions I received from both Prof. Hinton and my peers were often very helpful. That said, there came a point where I did feel that both I and my peers had gotten so deep into our individual projects that it was difficult for us to give full-bodied feedback to each other. In other words, it was hard to speak to others projects when not immersed in the same research that they were doing. As such, I think I wouldve appreciated maybe one or two more class sessions in which to either work independently or to meet with Prof. Hinton one-on-one.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: As AFAM 480 is required for the AFAM major, the question of whether Id recommend the course is also the question of whether Id recommend the AFAM major, to which the answer is a resounding yes. Ive been so pleased and excited by the AFAM Department during my time at Yale, both for its faculty/admin and for its courses. Its a department doing vital work and a department filled with some of the most generous people Ive met during my undergraduate years.
